ai-sn44:1.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn44:1.1.2_0: Now at that time the nun Khemā was wandering in the land of the Kosalans between Sāvatthī and Sāketa when she took up residence in Toraṇavatthu.
ai-sn44:1.1.3_0: Then King Pasenadi was traveling from Sāketa to Sāvatthī, and he too stayed in Toraṇavatthu for a single night.
ai-sn44:1.1.4_0: Then the Kosalan King Pasenadi addressed a certain man,
ai-sn44:1.1.5_0: “Please, mister, check if there’s a suitable ascetic or brahmin in Toraṇavatthu to whom I can pay homage.”
ai-sn44:1.2.1_0: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied that man. He searched all over Toraṇavatthu, but he couldn’t see a suitable ascetic or brahmin for the king to pay homage to.
ai-sn44:1.2.2_0: But he saw that the nun Khemā was staying there,
ai-sn44:1.2.3_0: He went to King Pasenadi and said to him,
ai-sn44:1.3.1_0: “Your Majesty, there’s no ascetic or brahmin in Toraṇavatthu for the king to pay homage to.
ai-sn44:1.3.2_0: But there is the nun Khemā, who’s a disciple of the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ai-sn44:1.3.3_0: She has a good reputation as being
ai-sn44:1.3.4_0: astute, competent, clever, learned, a brilliant speaker, and eloquent.
ai-sn44:1.3.5_0: Your Majesty may pay homage to her.”
ai-sn44:1.4.1_0: Then the Kosalan King Pasenadi approached the nun Khemā,
ai-sn44:1.4.1_1: and after approaching and worshipping the nun Khemā, he sat down on one side.

ai-sn44:2.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-sn44:2.1.2_0: Now at that time Venerable Anurādha was staying not far from the Buddha in a wilderness hut.
ai-sn44:2.1.3_0: Then several wanderers from other sects went to Venerable Anurādha,
ai-sn44:2.1.3_1: and after going, they exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn44:2.1.4_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side.
ai-sn44:2.1.5_0: “Reverend Anurādha, when a Realized One is describing a Realized One—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them in these four ways:
ai-sn44:2.1.6_0: After death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist’?”
ai-sn44:2.1.7_0: “Reverends, when a Realized One is describing a Realized One—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them other than these four ways:
ai-sn44:2.1.8_0: After death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.”
ai-sn44:2.1.9_0: When he said this, the wanderers said to him,
ai-sn44:2.1.10_0: “This mendicant must be junior, recently gone forth, or else a foolish, incompetent senior mendicant.”
ai-sn44:2.1.11_0: Then, after rebuking Venerable Anurādha by calling him “junior” and “foolish”, the wanderers got up from their seat and left.
ai-sn44:2.2.1_0: Soon after they had left, Anurādha thought:
ai-sn44:2.2.2_0: “If those wanderers were to inquire further,
ai-sn44:2.2.3_0: how should I answer them so as to repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? How should I explain in line with his teaching, so that there would be no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism?”
ai-sn44:2.2.4_0: Then Venerable Anurādha went up to the Buddha.
ai-sn44:2.2.5_0: “Sir, I was staying not far from the Buddha in a wilderness hut.
ai-sn44:2.2.6_0: Then several wanderers from other sects went to me,
ai-sn44:2.2.6_1: and after going, they exchanged greetings with me.
ai-sn44:2.2.7_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side.
ai-sn44:2.2.8_0: ‘Reverend Anurādha is a Realized One—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them in these four ways:
ai-sn44:2.2.10_0: “A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death”?’
ai-sn44:2.2.11_0: Sir, I said to those wanderers who follow other paths,
ai-sn44:2.2.12_0: ‘Reverends, when a Realized One is describing a Realized One—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them other than these four ways:
ai-sn44:2.2.14_0: “A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death”?’
ai-sn44:2.2.15_0: When I said this, those wanderers said to me:
ai-sn44:2.2.16_0: ‘This mendicant must be junior, recently gone forth, or else a foolish, incompetent senior mendicant.’
ai-sn44:2.2.17_0: Then, reverend Sir, those wanderers who follow other paths got up from their seat and left.
ai-sn44:2.2.18_0: Soon after I had left, I thought:
ai-sn44:2.2.19_0: ‘If those wanderers who follow other paths were further, I wouldn’t answer them. How would I answer them so as to repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? How should I explain in line with his teaching, with no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism?’”
ai-sn44:2.5.1_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”

ai-sn44:2.7.2_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

ai-sn44:2.15.1_0: “So, Anurādha, you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: *all* form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
